p:
The destination of the disperser is determined by the destination function
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\psi (x,y)$$\end{document}
ψ ( x , y )
, which determines probabilities of ending a dispersal event at
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$(x,y)$$\end{document}
( x , y )
, which results in a new sub-population being established at that location. In total, the spatial distribution of new sub-populations introduced by long-distance dispersal follows a Poisson point process of which intensities are given as
